book_title: Venture Deals: Be Smarter Than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist (Third Edition)
overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide to the people, documents, mechanics, and strategies that shape venture capital financings. The authors open by demystifying industry shorthand and profiling the players—entrepreneurs, angels, venture capitalists, lawyers, mentors and syndicates—showing how each actor's incentives and leverage influence outcomes. From a historical lens (e.g., AR&D's investment in DEC) they explain why the modern term sheet evolved into a multi-page negotiation focused on two core levers: economics (who gets paid what) and control (who makes the decisions).

The central portion of the book is a clause-by-clause deconstruction of the term sheet and related deal documents. It explains valuation, option pools, liquidation preferences, anti-dilution, vesting, board composition, protective provisions, registration and information rights, ROFR/co-sale mechanics, convertible debt (and SAFEs/KISS), and cap-table modeling—all with concrete examples and entrepreneur-focused guidance. Recurrent practical advice highlights which fights matter, which are negotiating posturing, and how lawyers and VCs commonly use language and structure to shift economics or governance.

Beyond mechanics the book foregrounds the entrepreneur's perspective: how to run a transparent company, handle exclusivity (no-shop) periods, accept standard protections while preserving founder upside, and spot red flags in investor behavior. It also covers essential legal housekeeping—entity choice, employment matters, and the critical 83(b) election—illustrating how early legal missteps can be costly or irreversible. The authors pair rigorous technical explanation with plain-language negotiation tactics so founders can evaluate tradeoffs and retain leverage where it matters.

Finally, the book situates deals within the larger startup ecosystem. It argues that startup communities are 'spiky' and offers the Boulder Thesis—a practical framework for building vibrant local ecosystems through entrepreneur-led, long-term, inclusive, activity-driven approaches. Taken together, the book is both a how-to manual for negotiating financings and a broader playbook for structuring startups, hiring and governance, and participating in healthy entrepreneurial communities.
key_themes: Economics vs. control: every negotiation resolves who benefits and who decides
Transparency and education: demystifying VC language empowers founders
Practical over theoretical: focus on clauses that materially affect exit economics
Process and people matter: fund types, lead investors, lawyers and mentors shape outcomes
Cap table literacy: precise math drives real ownership and dilution consequences
Legal housekeeping is strategic: entity choice, employment law, and tax elections matter
Community and ecosystem: startups flourish in long-term, entrepreneur-led communities
learning_objectives: Identify the core participants in venture financings and understand their incentives and leverage
Read, interpret, and prioritize term-sheet provisions based on their economic and control impact
Model pre-money/post-money cap tables, option-pool effects, and ownership after financing
Compare equity financings, convertible debt, SAFEs/KISS and bridge instruments and know when to use each
Spot common legal pitfalls (entity form, 83(b), IP assignment) and act early to avoid irreversible harm
Form negotiation strategies: when to concede, when to fight, how to create competitive dynamics

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

<!-- PageNumber="xiii" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="xiv Foreword" -->

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals: Be Smarter than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist, Third Edition By Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson Copyright @ 2016 by Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson" -->
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 4, "Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet," picks up the book's promise to demystify venture financings by focusing squarely on the people and the document that shape deals. Using the historical example of AR&D's investment in DEC, the chapter traces how the simple deal letter of the early VC era evolved into today's eight‑page term sheet. The authors emphasize that despite increased complexity and boilerplate, two fundamental levers drive every negotiation: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes key decisions). From there the chapter profiles the human players—venture capitalists across their hierarchy (MD/GP, partners, principals, associates, analysts), angels and super angels, syndicates and lead investors, entrepreneurs in residence, operating partners, and lawyers—explaining how each participant’s experience, incentives, and position of power affect the negotiation and ultimate governance of the company.

The chapter also covers practical fundraising mechanics that shape term sheet outcomes: financing‑round nomenclature (pre-seed, seed, Series A/B/C and extensions like B‑1), the risks of having too many small investors, the critical role of a capable VC‑savvy lawyer, and the importance of fundraising materials and demos. It stresses strategic elements—timing, creating competitive processes, aligning investor motivations, and doing homework on prospective firms—because the people and the process determine how the two core issues (economics and control) will be resolved in the term sheet.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 5 moves from the book's earlier framing about why term sheets matter (Chapters 2–4) into a practical, clause-by-clause tour of what entrepreneurs will actually see in a venture-capital term sheet. Building on the Introduction’s emphasis on people and leverage in deal-making, the chapter organizes term-sheet provisions around the two things VCs care about most—economics and control—and explains how price, preferences, option pools, warrants, vesting, antidilution, board composition, protective provisions, conversion, dividends, redemption rights, and conditions precedent each affect those two priorities. The authors provide entrepreneur-focused advice throughout: bring an option budget, avoid warrants when possible, prefer broad-based weighted-average antidilution to full ratchets, insist on balanced vesting and double-trigger acceleration, and beware of overly broad redemption or “adverse change” clauses and hidden binding conditions in otherwise nonbinding term sheets.

This chapter is the technical bridge in the book’s progression. Where earlier chapters explained why demystifying term sheets matters and who shapes them, Chapter 5 shows what to negotiate and why—translating high-level strategy into the specific provisions that determine who gets paid in an exit and who controls key decisions. It also introduces practical negotiation levers (e.g., creating competitive demand to raise price, using antidilution carve-outs, equalizing automatic-conversion thresholds across series) and flags common lawyer tactics and traps so entrepreneurs understand which fights matter and which are negotiable posturing.

Valuation and price is only one component of economics

Protective provisions and class voting dynamics
Conversion rights and automatic conversion thresholds
Dividends (cumulative vs noncumulative) and their economic impact
Redemption rights and the danger of 'adverse change' redemption
Conditions precedent and which term-sheet clauses are often binding

Control terms: board seats, protective provisions, conversion and voting
Founder/employee protections: vesting, exercise periods, acceleration
Other investor protections: dividends, redemption rights, conditions precedent
Negotiation strategy: which terms to prioritize and common investor tactics

The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Insist on spelling out key terms prior to a signed term sheet if it has a no-shop
clause in it. A VC who won't spell out key employment terms at the beginning
is a big red flag.

There are plenty of other wacky conditions-if you can dream it
up, it has probably been done. Just make sure to look carefully at this
paragraph and remember that you don't necessarily have a deal just
because you've signed a term sheet.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 shifts focus from clause anatomy (Chapter 5) and the human dynamics of dealmaking (Chapter 4) to the entrepreneur’s tactical posture once a term sheet appears. The central warning is practical: when a term sheet contains a no‑shop or exclusivity clause, entrepreneurs must insist that any key employment or deal‑critical terms be spelled out and agreed before the exclusivity period begins. If a VC refuses to commit to core employment terms up front, that behavior should be treated as a serious red flag about their intentions and respect for the entrepreneur’s position.

The chapter also flags the proliferation of odd or onerous provisions — “wacky conditions” — that can lurk in term sheets. Entrepreneurs are reminded to read every paragraph carefully and to remember that a signed term sheet (especially one with ambiguous or unexpressed key items) does not guarantee a closed financing. The practical lesson: preserve leverage by insisting on clarity early, scrutinize unusual clauses, and don’t assume formality equals finality.
key_concepts: Hidden or unusual term sheet conditions
main_topics: How exclusivity shifts leverage and the need for early clarity
The importance of spelling out employment terms before no‑shop takes effect
Vigilance for unusual or binding conditions in term sheets

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first
century. If you can't commit to sending your shareholders a budget and financial
statements, you shouldn't take on outside investors. If you are of the paranoid
mindset (which I generally applaud), feel free to insist on a strict confidentiality
clause to accompany your information rights.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 reframes the information-rights sections of a term sheet from the entrepreneur’s point of view: instead of treating investor demands for budgets, financial statements, and regular reporting as onerous intrusions, founders should see them as part of the bargain of taking outside capital. The chapter urges founders to run transparent organizations and to be willing to commit to regular reporting; if a founder cannot commit to sending basic financials and a budget, they probably should not take institutional investors. At the same time, the chapter acknowledges legitimate founder concerns about confidentiality and competitive sensitivity and recommends coupling ordinary information rights with a narrow confidentiality covenant where appropriate.

This guidance builds practical ground-level advice on top of the earlier structural discussion of term-sheet clauses and deal dynamics. Where Chapter 5 explained the anatomy of terms and Chapter 4 emphasized the people and leverage that shape deals, Chapter 7 applies those lessons to the reporting clauses entrepreneurs will actually negotiate. It stresses the trade-offs: transparency builds trust, simplifies future diligence and fundraising, and aligns incentives with investors, but it also requires careful drafting (e.g., limits on distribution, use, and timing of reports) to protect commercially sensitive details.
main_topics: Why entrepreneurs should accept investor information rights
How to structure reporting commitments reasonably
When and how to add confidentiality protections
Practical trade-offs between openness and competitive secrecy

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Don't focus much energy on registration rights. This is more about upside. The
world is good if you're going public.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 reframes everything an entrepreneur has learned about term sheets by putting the founder’s upside front and center. Whereas earlier chapters walked through clause anatomy (Chapter 5), the negotiation posture around exclusivity (Chapter 6), and the bargaining nature of information rights (Chapter 7), this chapter asks: how do those clauses affect the entrepreneur when the best possible outcome — an IPO — materializes? The tone shifts from defensive tactics to proactive economics: preserve founder participation in upside, structure rounds so that liquidation preferences, participation rights, anti-dilution mechanics, option pool sizing, and conversion terms don’t siphon away the value that an IPO would create.

The chapter stresses practical priorities. When the path to going public is realistic, many investor protections that feel threatening in the abstract (registration rights, some drag-along mechanics) become less consequential; what matters are the provisions that change how proceeds are shared at exit. Entrepreneurs should therefore focus negotiation energy on terms that materially affect post-exit economics and incentives, use information rights as a tool to demonstrate IPO readiness, and align governance so that the company can pursue a public offering without undue frictions. In short: think like an owner of the eventual public company and prioritize the clauses that will determine how much of the upside you and your team keep.
key_concepts: Anti-dilution provisions and their impact on later rounds
Using information rights to prepare for IPO
Registration rights as secondary — less central when IPO is likely
main_topics: Economic consequences of term-sheet clauses at exit
Negotiation priorities when an IPO is the target
Aligning investor protections with founder upside

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

The right of first refusal is not a big deal, and in some cases it's good for you.
But make sure you define what a major investor is and give this only to them. At
a minimum, you can make sure that shareholders get this right only if they play
in subsequent rounds.
chapter_summaries.summary: This chapter focuses on the restriction on sales—commonly called the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock—and the entrepreneur’s practical stance toward it. It defines the clause, shows typical term‑sheet language, and explains implementation choices (placing the ROFR in the bylaws versus in option agreements or plans). The authors trace the historical shift from an era when founders were broadly prevented from selling until investors liquidated, to today’s environment where robust secondary markets and longer times to liquidity make founder and employee secondaries common. Their conclusion: an ROFR on common is generally beneficial for the company and should be accepted by founders, provided it is drafted thoughtfully (e.g., limited to major investors or conditioned on participation in subsequent rounds).

Placement in bylaws vs option agreements/plans

The Entrepreneur's Perspective

A proprietary information and inventions agreement clause is good for the com-
pany. You should have all employees, including founders, sign something like
this before you do an outside venture financing. If someone on the team needs
a specific carve-out for work in progress that is unrelated to the business, you
and your investors should be willing to grant it.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This short chapter pushes the entrepreneur toward practical acceptance of certain investor protections while carving out modest founder flexibility. It affirms that proprietary information and inventions agreements (PIIAs) are standard and beneficial: every employee (including founders) should sign an assignment/confidentiality agreement before an outside financing so the company’s IP is clean. At the same time, the chapter counsels that reasonable carve-outs can and should be requested for truly unrelated preexisting or side work.

The chapter also addresses co-sale (co-sale/co-sale rights) and the right of first refusal dynamics from a founder’s perspective. While eliminating a co-sale clause entirely may be unrealistic, founders should ask for a “floor” so small, benign sales (for example, selling a few shares to finance a house) aren’t blocked or unduly delayed. Likewise, a ROFR that simply allows the company or investors to match a bona fide outside offer using that offer’s valuation is tolerable, but an ROFR implemented as an effective exclusion is not. The underlying message: accept standard investor protections that secure upside, but negotiate practical limits so founders retain minimal liquidity and reasonable flexibility.

Negotiating carve-outs
Managing co-sale restrictions
Acceptable forms of ROFR vs. effective exclusions
Balancing investor protections with founder flexibility

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you can't agree to a founders' activities clause, don't look for professional
VC financing. Or you can negotiate a very specific carve-out, and expect other
consequences in your terms (e.g., vesting and IP rights).
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter gives the entrepreneur a grounded, pragmatic view of a few standard term‑sheet provisions that founders will almost always face and should be prepared to accept or tightly limit. It opens with a blunt warning: if you cannot live with a founders’ activities clause (or cannot negotiate a very narrow carve‑out), professional VC money is probably not for you — and pushing back will likely trigger tradeoffs elsewhere (for example, stricter vesting or IP allocation). The chapter then treats three routine clauses in turn: the no‑shop agreement, indemnification of directors/investors, and the assignment clause. It explains what each clause typically says, why investors want it, how entrepreneurs can practically constrain it (e.g., time‑bound no‑shop periods of 30–60 days), and why — despite legal enforceability — the human element (VC credibility, reputation, and character) often drives real outcomes more than the precise wording.

The chapter builds the entrepreneur’s negotiating posture: accept that indemnification, and often D&O insurance, are standard and necessary to attract outside directors; allow reasonable assignment rights for VCs so they can operate their funds while insisting transferees remain bound by original agreements; and treat the no‑shop as a limited, reciprocal commitment designed to get a deal done quickly. It reinforces a recurring theme from earlier chapters — prioritize founder upside but be realistic about standard investor protections — and gives practical tactics (short, reciprocal no‑shop windows; insist that any transferee explicitly assume obligations; be aware of reputational signals from VCs) that will help founders navigate these provisions without wasting legal time or burning relationships.
key_concepts: Founders' activities clause (and consequences for refusing it)
No‑shop agreement (definition, typical language, time bounds)
Assignment clause for investors and transferee obligations
Practical vs. legal enforceability and the role of reputation
main_topics: Negotiating and bounding no‑shop agreements
Accepting indemnification and insurance expectations
Allowing VC assignment rights while preventing loopholes
Strategic tradeoffs when refusing standard investor protections

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. If you do this math, you'll

Class Shares Preferred Price Valuation Percentage
Founders 2,000,000 A
Employee pool B 20%
Venture investors C D $5,000,000 33.33%

see that (2 million + 857,081) * $3.50 = $9,999,783.50. Oops, we are off by $216.50, which represents 62 shares (well, 61.857 shares). While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. Although some get it right, it's your responsibility as the entrepreneur to make sure you understand your cap table. This will be especially helpful at times when you want to expand the employee option pool and you are eloquent in front of your board of directors explaining the ramifications.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 12 explains the capitalization table (cap table) that accompanies virtually every term sheet and shows, with a concrete numerical example, how ownership is allocated before and after a financing. Building on the term‑sheet concepts introduced earlier, the chapter walks through pre‑money and post‑money valuation, how a VC investment converts into a percentage ownership (e.g., $5M into a $15M post‑money = 33.33% for the investor), and how a required post‑money employee option pool is created and dilutes existing owners. The example computes total shares outstanding, the number of option‑pool shares, investor preferred shares, and the implied price per share, and it highlights the practical need for precision (fractional shares and extra decimals) rather than rounding early in the calculations.

The chapter reinforces a recurring theme from earlier chapters: founders must understand and own the mechanics of deals, not outsource critical analysis entirely to lawyers. Knowing how cap‑table math works is essential for evaluating term‑sheet tradeoffs (for example, how a demanded option pool or investor protections affect founder economics) and for explaining dilution and option‑pool expansions to boards and employees. The takeaway is both technical (how to compute shares, percentages, and prices) and strategic (how cap‑table design interacts with term‑sheet provisions and negotiating levers).

Entrepreneurial responsibility to verify cap math

Impact of option pool on founder ownership
Converting investment dollars into shares and price per share
Importance of precise arithmetic in cap tables
Practical implications for negotiating term sheets

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 13 builds directly on the term-sheet and cap-table foundations laid earlier by explaining convertible debt — a loan that converts into equity (usually preferred) at a future equity financing — and why it is commonly used at the seed stage. The chapter explains the two primary economic levers investors get: a discount to the next round's share price and a valuation cap that limits the conversion price. It then walks through conversion mechanics (what constitutes a Qualified Financing, maturity dates, automatic vs. optional conversion), governance risks from outstanding debt, the role and complexity of warrants (including original issue discount/accounting issues), and how convertible notes differ in early-stage versus bridge or late-stage contexts. It closes by comparing convertible notes with newer synthetic instruments (SAFE/KISS), noting tradeoffs such as maturity, pro-rata rights, and simplicity.
main_topics: Economic terms of convertible notes (discounts and caps)
Conversion mechanics and governance consequences
Warrants, accounting implications, and alternative instruments

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Legal Things Every Entrepreneur Should Know

T.
here are a few legal issues that we've seen consistently become
hurdles for entrepreneurs and their lawyers. While in some cases
they will simply be a hassle to clean up in a financing or an exit,
they often have meaningful financial implications for the company
and, in the worst case, can seriously damage the value of your busi-
ness. We aren't your lawyers or giving you legal advice here (our
lawyers made us write that), but we encourage you to understand
these issues rather than just assume that your lawyer got them right.

If you want to read the best book ever written on legal issues that
face entrepreneurs, get the book The Entrepreneur's Guide to Business
Law, Fourth Edition, by Constance Bagley and Craig Dauchy (South-
Western, 2012). It is written for entrepreneurs, not lawyers, so it's easily
digestible and is the best legal resource we know for entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 14 moves from deal mechanics to the practical legal housekeeping every entrepreneur must get right early. Building on the bargaining and structural concepts in earlier chapters, it focuses on three areas that routinely become painful, expensive, or irreversible if mishandled: employment matters (at-will status, severance, and having an employment lawyer), choice of entity (C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC) and its implications for future fundraising, and the critical tax timing issue of filing an 83(b) election for stock received subject to vesting. The authors stress that these are not theoretical items — they materially affect your ability to hire and fire, how you grant equity, your attractiveness to VCs, tax treatment on exit, and ultimately the company’s value.

The chapter is pragmatic: it reiterates how earlier technical choices (term-sheet provisions, cap table design, and convertible-debt mechanics) interact with legal form and employment practice. For example, the recommendation to form a C Corporation for VC/angel financing ties directly to the multi-class equity and preferred-stock structures introduced in Chapters 11–13; the 83(b) election is linked to vesting and option mechanics described previously (and is framed as a “do-it-or-pay-more-taxes” warning); and employment clauses (at-will language, severance, vesting acceleration) affect burn rate, option repurchases, and founder/employee incentives that show up in cap tables. The practical takeaway is clear: many financing and exit risks are best avoided or mitigated by addressing these legal items correctly at formation and hiring, because some mistakes can’t be fixed later.
key_concepts: Corporate structure: C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC
main_topics: Employment and termination risk management
Entity selection and fundraising compatibility
Tax timing for founder/employee equity (83(b))
Interaction of legal form with term sheets and cap tables
Practical legal hygiene and counsel
Reference resources and sample documents (glossary, term sheet, LOI)

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 15 shifts focus from deal mechanics and legal housekeeping to the place-based ecosystems that enable startups to form, scale, and persist. After noting that innovation is not location-neutral but rather “spiky,” the chapter surveys classical explanations (economics/agglomeration, sociology, geography) for why some regions concentrate entrepreneurial activity. Building on those frameworks, the author presents the Boulder Thesis: a practical, entrepreneur-centered model for building a vibrant startup community. The thesis has four pillars—entrepreneurs must lead, leaders must commit long-term (roughly a 20-year horizon), the community must be inclusive, and it must host continuous, hands-on activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter deepens two of those pillars. First, it argues that leaders must be entrepreneurial and hold a durable, multi-cycle commitment because building meaningful regional startup ecosystems spans many economic ups and downs. Second, it emphasizes tangible, recurring activities—hackathons, meetups, startup weekends, accelerators like TechStars—that engage first-time founders, veterans, investors, mentors, employees, and service providers. These practical, often time-bound programs are contrasted with ceremonial or purely social events; they produce real engagement, tolerate failure, and are iterated until something sticks. The chapter thus reframes community-building as a long-term, inclusive, activity-driven endeavor that complements the legal, financial, and structural topics covered earlier in the book.
main_topics: Historical frameworks for regional entrepreneurship
Practical model for community building (Boulder Thesis)
Importance of long-term, entrepreneur-led commitment
Designing inclusive, hands-on community activities
Resilience across economic cycles
